update.description:
Solution for issue #53. Optitrack viewpoint rotations are now disabled. Head motion tracking only induces translation in the user camera.

In order to get the rotations right, I had to add an offset between the camera position and the head marker position. Let me know if you'd like a longer explanation of these calculations.
update.title: Issue 53: Disable viewpoint rotations

content.raw: Perfect! I see you are an ASCII virtuoso.

content.raw:
A novel idea! The diagram we have in mind is more like a pose transform tree. In ASCII it would look something like...

```
G ---------> O --------> M ---> C
| \          \__________^ ^     ^
|  \______________________|     |
\______________________________/
```
content.html:
A novel idea! The diagram we have in mind is more like a pose transform tree. In ASCII it would look something like...

G ---------> O --------> M ---> C
| \          \__________^ ^     ^
|  \______________________|     |
\______________________________/

content.raw: One of the great features of doxygen and other simple formats like markdown is that you can still understand them when looking at the source. So a doxygenated header file is still useful as documentation when you are coding and looking at the header rather than the doxygen output. Nice diagrams in doxygen are possible and very tempting and we have succumbed on occasion; see [here](https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/latest/classSimTK_1_1MobilizedBody.html#details) for example. But then they are no help if you are looking in the header. So when feasible to do so, I think it is usually better to attempt some kind of ASCII artwork that is still decipherable in the header. Same goes for equations, like [this ugly example](https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/latest/singletonSimTK_1_1Rotation__.html#details).
content.html: One of the great features of doxygen and other simple formats like markdown is that you can still understand them when looking at the source. So a doxygenated header file is still useful as documentation when you are coding and looking at the header rather than the doxygen output. Nice diagrams in doxygen are possible and very tempting and we have succumbed on occasion; see here for example. But then they are no help if you are looking in the header. So when feasible to do so, I think it is usually better to attempt some kind of ASCII artwork that is still decipherable in the header. Same goes for equations, like this ugly example.

content.raw: Can you describe what's happening here? if `viewPointRotationsEnabled`, then we skip adding `cameraToOptitrackHead` transform altogether, otherwise we add `cameraToOptitrackHead` transform?  If this is doing what I think it does, it's not very clear to me how `cameraToOptitrackHead` cancels out rotations from the sensors?
content.html: Can you describe what's happening here? if viewPointRotationsEnabled, then we skip adding cameraToOptitrackHead transform altogether, otherwise we add cameraToOptitrackHead transform? If this is doing what I think it does, it's not very clear to me how cameraToOptitrackHead cancels out rotations from the sensors?

content.raw:
for me personally, regarding transforms... a picture is worth a thousand words. Actually, it's the only time I can do transforms correctly. So I started sketching things out.  In my commit, 2189b98, I enabled

~~~
make transforms
~~~

and turned on equation numbers.

So, here's my first comment: equation (2) in gazebo math should look like this:
~~~
C_oi = (-M_c) + M_ot
~~~
This way, we leverage pose math, and don't have to deal with our own potential rotation errors. Note, don't omit the parenthesis to make sure the right pose math is performed.

For equation (3), we can compute the entire transform from Gazebo world frame to the Optitrack frame specified in Gazebo world frame (and get translation only if desired):
~~~
M_g^o = C_gi + (-C_oi)
~~~
Again, note, don't omit the parenthesis to make sure the correct pose math is performed.

Next, for equation (5), do
~~~
C_od = M_ot + (-M_c)
~~~

I am not sure what O_g is... if it's what I think it is... the transform of Optitrack frame specified in the Gazebo world frame, or what I called

~~~
M_g^o
~~~
above, then equation (6) is now:

~~~
C_gd = C_od + M_g^o
~~~

All the equations above using simple Gazebo Pose math.
content.html:
for me personally, regarding transforms... a picture is worth a thousand words. Actually, it's the only time I can do transforms correctly. So I started sketching things out. In my commit, 2189b98, I enabled

make transforms

and turned on equation numbers.

So, here's my first comment: equation (2) in gazebo math should look like this:

C_oi = (-M_c) + M_ot

This way, we leverage pose math, and don't have to deal with our own potential rotation errors. Note, don't omit the parenthesis to make sure the right pose math is performed.

For equation (3), we can compute the entire transform from Gazebo world frame to the Optitrack frame specified in Gazebo world frame (and get translation only if desired):

M_g^o = C_gi + (-C_oi)

Again, note, don't omit the parenthesis to make sure the correct pose math is performed.

Next, for equation (5), do

C_od = M_ot + (-M_c)

I am not sure what O_g is... if it's what I think it is... the transform of Optitrack frame specified in the Gazebo world frame, or what I called

M_g^o

above, then equation (6) is now:

C_gd = C_od + M_g^o

All the equations above using simple Gazebo Pose math.

content.raw: [disable_viewpoint_rotations_gerkey](#!/osrf/handsim/branch/disable_viewpoint_rotations_gerkey) has the net result of my efforts this afternoon.  I was able to avoid the jump at start with a minor [rearrangement of terms](#!/osrf/handsim/commits/532d074a2806bdba2eaee89c1ffbe907fd3d2e18?at=default#Lsrc/HaptixControlPlugin.ccT1446), but that change introduces an error in the relationship between the camera and the marker that's very noticeable when rotating.  I then proceeded to fix that, and ended up back with the jump at start.
content.html: disable_viewpoint_rotations_gerkey has the net result of my efforts this afternoon. I was able to avoid the jump at start with a minor rearrangement of terms, but that change introduces an error in the relationship between the camera and the marker that's very noticeable when rotating. I then proceeded to fix that, and ended up back with the jump at start.

content.raw: Finished in  bc48163. Publishing a non-zero integer to topic "~/motion_tracking/viewpoint_rotations" will turn on viewpoint rotations, publisher zero will turn them off. The current default is on. When we add a GUI button to toggle them, the GUI should publish to this topic.
content.html: Finished in bc48163. Publishing a non-zero integer to topic "~/motion_tracking/viewpoint_rotations" will turn on viewpoint rotations, publisher zero will turn them off. The current default is on. When we add a GUI button to toggle them, the GUI should publish to this topic.
